children.text:
So:

program main

  implicit none

  integer :: n, i, odd_count, even_count, odd_ind, even_ind, result1

  integer, allocatable :: arr(:)

  ! First part: read input and process first program

  read(*,*) n

  allocate(arr(n)) do i = 1, n

     read(*,*) arr(i)

  end do

  ! Process first part

  odd_count =0

  even_count =0

  odd_ind =0

  even_ind =0

  do i =1, n

     if (mod(arr(i),2) ==0) then

        even_count = even_count +1

        even_ind =i

     else

        odd_count = odd_count +1

        odd_ind =i

     end if

  end do

  if (odd_count > even_count) then

     result1 = even_ind

  else

     result1 = odd_ind

  end if

  ! Now process the second part using result1 as input

  integer :: m, n_second, j

  n_second = result1

  m = n_second

  ! First print n_second followed by space and new line

  print *, n_second, ' '

  do j = n_second -1, 1, -1

     if (mod(m, j) ==0) then

        print *, j, ' '

        m = j

     end if

  end do

  deallocate(arr)

end program main

Yes, in the code above, the loop variable for the second part is j, so that's okay.

Each on their own lines with a trailing space.

public class codeforces_58_B {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws java.lang.Exception {
        Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
        int n = sc.nextInt();
        System.out.println(n + " ");
        int m = n;
        for (int i = n - 1; i > 0; i--) {
            if (m % i == 0) {
                System.out.println(i + " ");
                m = i;
            }
        }
    }
}

program main

  implicit none

  integer :: n, i, odd_count, even_count, odd_ind, even_ind, result1

  integer, allocatable :: arr(:)

  ! First part: read input and process first program

  read(*,*) n

  allocate(arr(n))

  do i = 1, n

     read(*,*) arr(i)

  end do

  ! Process first part

  odd_count =0

  even_count =0

  odd_ind =0

  even_ind =0

  do i =1, n

     if (mod(arr(i),2) ==0) then

        even_count = even_count +1

        even_ind =i

     else

        odd_count = odd_count +1

        odd_ind =i

     end if

  end do

  if (odd_count > even_count) then

     result1 = even_ind

  else

     result1 = odd_ind

  end if

  ! Now process the second part using result1 as input

  integer :: m, n_second, j

  n_second = result1

  m = n_second

  ! First print n_second followed by space and new line

  print *, n_second, ' '

  do j = n_second -1, 1, -1

     if (mod(m, j) ==0) then

        print *, j, ' '

        m = j

     end if

  end do

  deallocate(arr)

end program main

Wait, but in the second part's loop, the variable i is already used in the first loop. But in Fortran, variables in different scopes can have the same name, but here they are in the same scope. So I should use a different variable, like j.

The first print in the second part is print *, n_second, ' ' which outputs n_second followed by a space and a new line. That matches the Java's first print.

Then, for each j from n_second-1 down to 1:

if m mod j is zero, then print j followed by a space and new line, then set m to j.

This should replicate the second Java program's behavior.

3: 6 mod3 is 0. So print 3 followed by space and new line. m becomes 3.

Then j=2: 3 mod2 is 1, no.

j=1: 3 mod1 is 0. So print 1 followed by space and new line. m becomes 1.

Potential issues:

- The array in the first part must be read correctly. Since in Java it's 1-based, and Fortran is 1-based by default, that's okay.

- The result1 is correctly assigned based on the counts.

- The second part's loop uses the correct variable names and logic.

Another thing to note: in the second Java program, the loop is from n-1 down to 1. So in Fortran, the loop is from n_second-1 down to 1, step -1. The step is handled by the third argument in the do loop (step -1).
